passages.text: August 29, 2025 05:40 AM GMT
Japan Economics | Japan
August Tokyo CPI Relentiny Report: Impact from Energy- Related Factor
Impact of utility subsidies and water charge waiver- Weighted median CPI remains flat
Impact of utility subsidies/water charge waiver: In Aug preliminary Tokyo CPI, Japan- style core CPI (excl. fresh food) rose \(2.5\%\) YoY, down from \(2.9\%\) in July, matching market expectations.

Electricity and gas subsidies were reintroduced for usage during Jul- Sep (reflected in CPI from Aug- Oct). As a result, electricity and gas prices fell sharply, significantly increasing their negative contribution to the Aug Tokyo CPI. Also, as a temporary summer measure, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government began waiving basic water charges for all general households in Tokyo in June, for a period of four months. This one- off factor should be noted as it also influenced the CPI. Food prices excl. fresh items rose \(7.4\%\) , marking the third consecutive month of increases above \(7\%\) . Although the rate of rice price increase narrowed by 13.9pt from the previous month, prices still rose \(67.9\%\) YoY, remaining high.

Weighted median CPI remains flat: By our estimates, the weighted median, which reflects the underlying trend in Tokyo's CPI, was \(+1.1\%\) YoY, nearly unchanged from last month. Given that the nationwide CPI- based weighted median had slowed to \(1.1\%\) in July, whether the nationwide August figure falls below \(1\%\) is likely to draw market attention. That said, in a recent speech by Boj Policy Board Member Junko Nakagawa, it was noted (based on the distribution of item- level CPI price changes) that "the tails of the distribution have been extended upward, and the simple median has been at around 2 percent," potentially suggesting policy implications for the underlying inflation trend. (For more details, please see our report.)
Exhibit 1: Tokyo CPI: Headline, Japan-style core, US-style core (% YoY)
Source: MiC, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 2: Weighted median CPI: Tokyo vs. Nationwide (%YoY)
Source: MiC, BoJ, Morgan Stanley Research estimates
